thread.title: Hairopoulos: 'We were ready,' says OU's Stoops; doubts surface about Sooners' contender status
thread.title_full: Hairopoulos: 'We were ready,' says OU's Stoops; doubts surface about Sooners' contender status | Dallas Morning News

author: Kate Hairopoulos
title: Hairopoulos: 'We were ready,' says OU's Stoops; doubts surface about Sooners' contender status
text:
As Texas' Marcus Johnson swept 24 yards into a Cotton Bowl end zone early Saturday, one ... two ... three ... four Oklahoma Sooners tried to stop him and whiffed.
Meanwhile, the Longhorns had no such trouble bear-hugging OU quarterback Baker Mayfield early and repeatedly.
The No. 10 Sooners had talked about this very possibility all week, guarded against it, but once the 24-17 loss was in motion, couldn't make it stop.
And for the second time in three years, they're left trying to understand why they couldn't deliver as two-touchdown favorites against their Red River rivals, previously verging on wheels-off status.
"In the locker room we were pumped," OU linebacker Dominique Alexander said. "We wanted to come out here and dominate."
Instead, UT led the Sooners 14-0 less than 10 minutes into the game.
"It didn't get away," OU coach Bob Stoops said. "14 points isn't [getting] away. It surely didn't get off great, but in the end I do feel like we were ready. We got out-leveraged, missed some tackles. I don't think it's 'cause you're not ready. I don't look at it that way. We knew they had been in some tight, tough games. And we knew what they were capable of.
"They covered us, they pressured us, they controlled the line of scrimmage. ... Did I miss anything?"
Since Stoops asked:
OU mustered only 67 yards rushing on 37 attempts and 278 yards total after averaging 521.8 yards of total offense in its first four games.
Mayfield and the beleaguered offensive line took six sacks, including two on a drive late in the fourth quarter with the Sooners down seven.
OU gave up 313 yards rushing to one-dimensional UT, including an 81-yard run by D'Onta Foreman up the middle that the Sooners said they were prepared for.
The previously undefeated Sooners also had lost to a struggling Texas team 36-20 in 2013 after being heavily favored. That was referenced often this week, considering UT entered the game coming off a 50-7 loss to TCU and surrounded by a burnt orange sense of doom.
But now it's OU's ineffectiveness and doubts about its ability to contend in the Big 12 with No. 2 TCU and No. 3 Baylor that will be obsessed over.
"We walked into a lion's den here today," defensive coordinator Mike Stoops said. "And that's what happens. People back you into a corner, and they come out fighting. And that's a prideful program. You'd be foolish to think they wouldn't.
"We kind of got set up for this and couldn't respond in a more positive way.
"That's the disappointing part. Still, we had our chances."
OU twice pulled within a touchdown of Texas in the second half, in part because Mayfield (20 of 28 for 211 yards) was able to make some big passing plays and determined runs. He completed 14 of 16 passes for 166 yards and a touchdown in the second half.
"When a team's bringing as much pressure as Texas was, you've got to settle in and let the bullets fly by and make the throws," offensive coordinator Lincoln Riley said. "It took him a little longer to settle in."
But when OU had the ball, down seven with 6:05 to play, the Sooners gave up two more sacks and had to punt. Texas got the ball back with 3:33 to play and converted three first downs to run out the clock.
"Everyone's got to take a step back and get a lot better," Riley said. "There was no overlooking, I know that's where you're going. You know how these games go. These guys were ready to play. We knew we were going to get everything Texas had. The defense played well enough to win. 24 points is plenty to win a Big 12 game."
But it wasn't, not on this Saturday, and that's what the Sooners are left trying to make sense of.
